column2: Chords of not more than four tones for each hand may be played simultaneously on the harp, but arpeggio and scale passages are the rule, and are more successful than simultaneous chords.
column3: Chords of not more than four tones for each hand may be played simultaneously on the harp, but arpeggio and scale passages are the rule, and are more successful than simultaneous chords.

column2: The notation of harp music is essentially like that of piano music.

column2: NOTE:--It is usually taken for granted that the student of music is familiar with the significance of such terms as _over-tone_, _equal temperament_, etc., and with principles such as that relating to the relation between vibration rates and pitches: the writer has in his own experience found, however, that most students are not at all familiar with such data, and this appendix is therefore added in the hope that a few facts at least regarding the laws of sound may be brought to the attention of some who would otherwise remain in entire ignorance of the subject.
column3: NOTE:--It is usually taken for granted that the student of music is familiar with the significance of such terms as underscore over tone underscore, underscore equal temperament underscore, etc, and with principles such as that relating to the relation between vibration rates and pitches: the writer has in his own experience found, however, that most students are not at all familiar with such data, and this appendix is therefore added in the hope that a few facts at least regarding the laws of sound may be brought to the attention of some who would otherwise remain in entire ignorance of the subject.

column2: _Acoustics_ is the science which deals with sound and the laws of its production and transmission.
column3: underscore Acoustics underscore is the science which deals with sound and the laws of its production and transmission.

column2: Since all sound is caused by vibration, _acoustics_ may be defined as the science which treats of the phenomena of sound-producing vibration.
column3: Since all sound is caused by vibration, underscore acoustics underscore may be defined as the science which treats of the phenomena of sound producing vibration.
two.

column2: All sound (as stated above) is produced by vibration of some sort: strike a tuning-fork against the top of a table and _see_ the vibrations which cause the tone, or, if the fork is a small one and the vibrations cannot be seen, hold it against the edge of a sheet of paper and hear the blows it strikes; or, watch one of the lowest strings of the piano after striking the key a sharp blow; or, look closely at the heavier strings of the violin (or better still, the cello) and watch them oscillate rapidly to and fro as the bow moves across them.
column3: All sound (as stated above) is produced by vibration of some sort: strike a tuning fork against the top of a table and underscore see underscore the vibrations which cause the tone, or, if the fork is a small one and the vibrations cannot be seen, hold it against the edge of a sheet of paper and hear the blows it strikes; or, watch one of the lowest strings of the piano after striking the key a sharp blow; or, look closely at the heavier strings of the violin (or better still, the cello) and watch them oscillate rapidly to and fro as the bow moves across them.

column2: The vibrating body may be a string, a thin piece of wood, a piece of metal, a membrane (cf. drum), the lips (cf. playing the cornet), the vocal cords, etc.
column3: The vibrating body may be a string, a thin piece of wood, a piece of metal, a membrane (c f. drum), the lips (c f. playing the cornet), the vocal cords, etc

column2: Often it is a column of air whose vibrations give rise to the tone, the reed or other medium merely serving to set the air in vibration.
column3: Often it is a column of air whose vibrations give rise to the tone, the reed or other medium merely serving to set the air in vibration.
three.

column2: Sound is _transmitted_ through the air in somewhat this fashion: the vibrating body (a string for example) strikes the air-particles in its immediate vicinity, and they, being in contact with other such air-particles, strike these others, the latter in turn striking yet others, and so on, both a forward and backward movement being set up (oscillation).
column3: Sound is underscore transmitted underscore through the air in somewhat this fashion: the vibrating body (a string for example) strikes the air particles in its immediate vicinity, and they, being in contact with other such air particles, strike these others, the latter in turn striking yet others, and so on, both a forward and backward movement being set up (oscillation).

column2: These particles lie so close together that no movement at all can be detected, and it is only when the disturbance finally reaches the air-particles that are in contact with the ear-drum that any effect is evident.
column3: These particles lie so close together that no movement at all can be detected, and it is only when the disturbance finally reaches the air particles that are in contact with the ear drum that any effect is evident.

column2: This phenomenon of sound-transmission may perhaps be made more clear by the old illustration of a series of eight billiard balls in a row on a table: if the first ball is tapped lightly, striking gently against ball number 2, the latter (as well as numbers 3, 4, 5, 6, and 7) will not apparently move at all, but ball number 8 at the other end will roll away.
column3: This phenomenon of sound transmission may perhaps be made more clear by the old illustration of a series of eight billiard balls in a row on a table: if the first ball is tapped lightly, striking gently against ball number two, the latter (as well as numbers three, four, five, six, and seven) will not apparently move at all, but ball number eight at the other end will roll away.

column2: The air-particles act upon each other in much this same fashion, the difference being that when they are set in motion by a vibrating body a complete vibration backward and forward causes a similar _backward and forward_ movement of the particles (oscillation) instead of simply a _forward jerk_ as in the case of the billiard balls.
column3: The air particles act upon each other in much this same fashion, the difference being that when they are set in motion by a vibrating body a complete vibration backward and forward causes a similar underscore backward and forward underscore movement of the particles (oscillation) instead of simply a underscore forward jerk underscore as in the case of the billiard balls.

column2: Another way of describing the same process is this: the vibration of some body produces waves in the air (cf. waves in the ocean, which carry water forward but do not themselves move on continuously), these waves spread out spherically (i.e. in all directions) and finally reach the ear, where they set the ear-drum in vibration, thus sending certain sound-stimuli to the nerves of hearing in the inner ear, and thus to the brain.
column3: Another way of describing the same process is this: the vibration of some body produces waves in the air (c f. waves in the ocean, which carry water forward but do not themselves move on continuously), these waves spread out spherically (i e in all directions) and finally reach the ear, where they set the ear drum in vibration, thus sending certain sound stimuli to the nerves of hearing in the inner ear, and thus to the brain.

column2: An important thing to be noted in connection with sound-transmission is that sound will not travel in a vacuum: some kind of a medium is essential for its transmission.
column3: An important thing to be noted in connection with sound transmission is that sound will not travel in a vacuum: some kind of a medium is essential for its transmission.

column2: This medium may be air, water, a bar of iron or steel, the earth, etc.
column3: This medium may be air, water, a bar of iron or steel, the earth, etc
four.

column2: The _rate_ at which sound travels through the air is about 1100 feet per second, the rapidity varying somewhat with fluctuations in temperature and humidity.
column3: The underscore rate underscore at which sound travels through the air is about one thousand one hundred feet per second, the rapidity varying somewhat with fluctuations in temperature and humidity.

column2: In water the rate is much higher than in air (about four times as great) while the velocity of sound through other mediums (as _e.g._, steel) is sometimes as much as sixteen times as great as through air.
column3: In water the rate is much higher than in air (about four times as great) while the velocity of sound through other mediums (as underscore e g underscore, steel) is sometimes as much as sixteen times as great as through air.

column2: Sound, like light, may be _intensified_ by a suitable reflecting surface directly back of the vibrating body (cf. sounding board); it may also be reflected by some surface at a distance from its source in such a way that at a certain point (the focus) the sound may be very clearly heard, but at other places, even those _nearer_ the source of sound, it can scarcely be heard at all.
column3: Sound, like light, may be underscore intensified underscore by a suitable reflecting surface directly back of the vibrating body (c f. sounding board); it may also be reflected by some surface at a distance from its source in such a way that at a certain point (the focus) the sound may be very clearly heard, but at other places, even those underscore nearer underscore the source of sound, it can scarcely be heard at all.

column2: If there is such a surface in an auditorium (as often occurs) there will be a certain point where everything can be heard very easily, but in the rest of the room it may be very difficult to understand what is being said or sung.
column3: If there is such a surface in an auditorium (as often occurs) there will be a certain point where everything can be heard very easily, but in the rest of the room it may be very difficult to understand what is being said or sung.

column2: _Echoes_ are caused by sound-reflection, the distance of the reflecting surface from the vibrating body determining the number of syllables that will be echoed.
column3: underscore Echoes underscore are caused by sound reflection, the distance of the reflecting surface from the vibrating body determining the number of syllables that will be echoed.

column2: The _acoustics_ of an auditorium (_i.e._, its hearing properties) depend upon the position and nature of the reflecting surfaces and also upon the length of time a sound persists after the vibrating body has stopped.
column3: The underscore acoustics underscore of an auditorium (underscore i e underscore, its hearing properties) depend upon the position and nature of the reflecting surfaces and also upon the length of time a sound persists after the vibrating body has stopped.

column2: If it persists longer than 2-1/4 or 2-1/3 seconds the room will not be suitable for musical performances because of the mixture of persisting tones with following ones, this causing a blurred effect somewhat like that obtained by playing a series of unrelated chords on the piano while the damper-pedal is held down.
column3: If it persists longer than two minus one quarter or two to one third of a second the room will not be suitable for musical performances because of the mixture of persisting tones with following ones, this causing a blurred effect somewhat like that obtained by playing a series of unrelated chords on the piano while the damper pedal is held down.

column2: The duration of the reverberation depends upon the size and height of the room, material of floor and walls, furniture, size of audience, etc.
column3: The duration of the reverberation depends upon the size and height of the room, material of floor and walls, furniture, size of audience, etc

column2: Sound may be classified roughly into _tones_ and _noises_ although the line of cleavage is not always sharply drawn.
column3: Sound may be classified roughly into underscore tones underscore and underscore noises underscore although the line of cleavage is not always sharply drawn.

column2: If I throw stones at the side of a barn, sounds are produced, but they are caused by irregular vibrations of an irregularly constructed surface and are referred to as _noise_.
column3: If I throw stones at the side of a barn, sounds are produced, but they are caused by irregular vibrations of an irregularly constructed surface and are referred to as underscore noise underscore.

column2: But if I tap the head of a kettle-drum, a regular series of vibrations is set up and the resulting sound is referred to as _tone_.
column3: But if I tap the head of a kettle drum, a regular series of vibrations is set up and the resulting sound is referred to as underscore tone underscore.

column2: In general the material of music consists of tones, but for special effects certain noises are also utilized (cf. castanets, etc.).
column3: In general the material of music consists of tones, but for special effects certain noises are also utilized (c f. castanets, etc).

column3: Pitch.

column2: By _pitch_ is meant the highness or lowness of tone.
column3: By underscore pitch underscore is meant the highness or lowness of tone.

column2: It depends upon rate of vibration.
column3: It depends upon rate of vibration.

column2: If a body vibrates only 8 or 10 times per second no tone is heard at all: but if it vibrates regularly at the rate of 16 or 18 per second a tone of very low pitch is heard.
column3: If a body vibrates only eight or ten times per second no tone is heard at all: but if it vibrates regularly at the rate of sixteen or eighteen per seconds a tone of very low pitch is heard.

column2: If it vibrates at the rate of 24 the pitch is higher, at 30 higher still, at 200 yet higher, and when a rate of about 38,000 per second has been reached the pitch is so high that most ears cannot perceive it at all.
column3: If it vibrates at the rate of twenty four the pitch is higher, at thirty higher still, at two hundred yet higher, and when a rate of about thirty eight thousand per seconds has been reached the pitch is so high that most ears cannot perceive it at all.

column2: The highest tone that can ordinarily be heard is the E[flat] four octaves higher than the highest E[flat] of the piano.
column3: The highest tone that can ordinarily be heard is the E[flat] four octaves higher than the highest E[flat] of the piano.

column2: The entire range of sound humanly audible is therefore about eleven octaves (rates 16-38,000), but only about _eight_ of these octaves are utilized for musical purposes.
column3: The entire range of sound humanly audible is therefore about eleven octaves (rates sixteen minus thirty eight thousand), but only about underscore eight underscore of these octaves are utilized for musical purposes.

column2: The tones of the piano (with a range of 7-1/3 octaves) are produced by vibration rates approximately between 27 and 4224.
column3: The tones of the piano (with a range of seven minus one third octaves) are produced by vibration rates approximately between twenty seven and four thousand two hundred twenty four.

column2: In the orchestra the range is slightly more extended, the rates being from 33 to 4752.
column3: In the orchestra the range is slightly more extended, the rates being from thirty three to four thousand seven hundred fifty two.

column2: Certain interesting facts regarding the relation between vibration-rates and pitches have been worked out: it has been discovered for instance that if the number of vibrations is doubled, the pitch of the resulting tone is an octave higher; _i.e._, if a string vibrating at the rate of 261 per second gives rise to the pitch c', then a string one-half as long and vibrating twice as rapidly (522) will give rise to the pitch c'', _i.e._, an octave higher than c'.
column3: Certain interesting facts regarding the relation between vibration rates and pitches have been worked out: it has been discovered for instance that if the number of vibrations is doubled, the pitch of the resulting tone is an octave higher; underscore i e underscore, if a string vibrating at the rate of two hundred sixty one per seconds gives rise to the pitch c', then a string one half as long and vibrating twice as rapidly (five hundred twenty two) will give rise to the pitch c'', underscore i e underscore, an octave higher than c'.

column2: In the same way it has been found that if the rate is multiplied by 5/4 the pitch of the tone will be a _major third_ higher; if multiplied by 3/2, a _perfect fifth_ higher, etc.
column3: In the same way it has been found that if the rate is multiplied by five quarters the pitch of the tone will be a underscore major third underscore higher; if multiplied by three halves, a underscore perfect fifth underscore higher, etc

column2: These laws are often stated thus: the ratio of the octave to the fundamental is as two is to one; that of the major third as five is to four; that of the perfect fifth as three is to two, and so on through the entire series of pitches embraced within the octave, the _ratio_ being of course the same for all octaves.
column3: These laws are often stated thus: the ratio of the octave to the fundamental is as two is to one; that of the major third as five is to four; that of the perfect fifth as three is to two, and so on through the entire series of pitches embraced within the octave, the underscore ratio underscore being of course the same for all octaves.

column2: The _intensity_ (loudness or softness) of tones depends upon the amplitude (width) of the vibrations, a louder tone being the result of vibrations of greater amplitude, and vice versa.
column3: The underscore intensity underscore (loudness or softness) of tones depends upon the amplitude (width) of the vibrations, a louder tone being the result of vibrations of greater amplitude, and vice versa.

column2: This may be verified by plucking a long string (on cello or double-bass) and noting that when plucked gently vibrations of small amplitude are set up, while a vigorous pluck results in much wider vibrations, and, consequently, in a louder tone.
column3: This may be verified by plucking a long string (on cello or double bass) and noting that when plucked gently vibrations of small amplitude are set up, while a vigorous pluck results in much wider vibrations, and, consequently, in a louder tone.

column2: It should be noted that the _pitch_ of the tone is not affected by the change in amplitude of vibration.
column3: It should be noted that the underscore pitch underscore of the tone is not affected by the change in amplitude of vibration.

column2: The intensity of tones varies with the medium conveying them, being usually louder at night because the air is then more elastic.
column3: The intensity of tones varies with the medium conveying them, being usually louder at night because the air is then more elastic.

column2: Tone intensity is also affected by _sympathetic vibrations_ set up in other bodies.
column3: Tone intensity is also affected by underscore sympathetic vibrations underscore set up in other bodies.

column2: If two strings of the same length are stretched side by side and one set in vibration so as to produce tone the other will soon begin to vibrate also and the combined tone will be louder than if only one string produced it.
column3: If two strings of the same length are stretched side by side and one set in vibration so as to produce tone the other will soon begin to vibrate also and the combined tone will be louder than if only one string produced it.

column2: This phenomenon is the basis of what is known as resonance (cf. body of violin, resonance cavities of nose and mouth, sounding board of piano, etc.).
column3: This phenomenon is the basis of what is known as resonance (c f. body of violin, resonance cavities of nose and mouth, sounding board of piano, etc).

column2: _Quality_ depends upon the shape (or form) of the vibrations which give rise to the tone.
column3: underscore Quality underscore depends upon the shape (or form) of the vibrations which give rise to the tone.

column2: A series of simple vibrations will cause a simple (or colorless) tone, while complex vibrations (giving rise to overtones of various kinds and in a variety of proportions) cause more individualistic peculiarities of quality.
column3: A series of simple vibrations will cause a simple (or colorless) tone, while complex vibrations (giving rise to overtones of various kinds and in a variety of proportions) cause more individualistic peculiarities of quality.

column2: Practically every musical tone really consists of a combination of several tones sounding simultaneously, the combined effect upon the ear giving the impression of a single tone.
column3: Practically every musical tone really consists of a combination of several tones sounding simultaneously, the combined effect upon the ear giving the impression of a single tone.

column2: The most important tone of the series is the _fundamental_, which dominates the combination and gives the pitch, but this fundamental is practically always combined with a greater or less number of faint and elusive attending tones called _overtones_ or _harmonics_.
column3: The most important tone of the series is the underscore fundamental underscore, which dominates the combination and gives the pitch, but this fundamental is practically always combined with a greater or less number of faint and elusive attending tones called underscore overtones underscore or underscore harmonics underscore.

column2: The first of these overtones is the octave above the fundamental; the second is the fifth above this octave; the third, two octaves above the fundamental, and so on through the series as shown in the figure below.
column3: The first of these overtones is the octave above the fundamental; the second is the fifth above this octave; the third, two octaves above the fundamental, and so on through the series as shown in the figure below.

column2: The presence of these _overtones_ is accounted for by the fact that the string (or other vibrating body) does not merely vibrate in its entirety but has in addition to the principal oscillation a number of sectional movements also.
column3: The presence of these underscore overtones underscore is accounted for by the fact that the string (or other vibrating body) does not merely vibrate in its entirety but has in addition to the principal oscillation a number of sectional movements also.

column2: Thus it is easily proved that a string vibrates in halves, thirds, etc., in addition to the principal vibration of the entire string, and it is the vibration of these halves, thirds, etc., which gives rise to the _harmonics_, or _upper partials_ as they are often called.
column3: Thus it is easily proved that a string vibrates in halves, thirds, etc, in addition to the principal vibration of the entire string, and it is the vibration of these halves, thirds, etc, which gives rise to the underscore harmonics underscore, or underscore upper partials underscore as they are often called.

column2: Thus _e.g._, a tone that has too large a proportion of the fourth upper partial (_i.e._, the _third_ of the chord) will be _reedy_ and somewhat unpleasant.

column2: Too great a proportion of overtones is what causes certain pianos to sound "tin-panny." The tone produced by a good tuning-fork is almost entirely free from overtones: it has therefore no distinctive quality and is said to be a _simple_ tone.
column3: Too great a proportion of overtones is what causes certain pianos to sound "tin panny." The tone produced by a good tuning fork is almost entirely free from overtones: it has therefore no distinctive quality and is said to be a underscore simple underscore tone.

column2: The characteristic tone of the oboe on the other hand has many overtones and is therefore highly individualistic: this enables us to recognize the tone of the instrument even though we cannot see the player.
column3: The characteristic tone of the oboe on the other hand has many overtones and is therefore highly individualistic: this enables us to recognize the tone of the instrument even though we cannot see the player.

column2: Such a tone is said to be _complex_.

column2: The mathematical ratio referred to on page 134, if strictly carried out in tuning a keyboard instrument would cause the half-steps to vary slightly in size, and playing in certain keys (especially those having a number of sharps or flats in the signature) would therefore sound out of tune.

column2: There would be many other disadvantages in such a system, notably the inability to modulate freely to other keys, and since modulation is one of the predominant and most striking characteristics of modern music, this would constitute a serious barrier to advances in composition.
column3: There would be many other disadvantages in such a system, notably the inability to modulate freely to other keys, and since modulation is one of the predominant and most striking characteristics of modern music, this would constitute a serious barrier to advances in composition.

column2: To obviate these disadvantages a system of _equal temperament_ was invented and has been in universal use since the time of Bach (1685-1750) who was the first prominent composer to use it extensively.
column3: To obviate these disadvantages a system of underscore equal temperament underscore was invented and has been in universal use since the time of Bach (sixteen eighty five to seventeen fifty) who was the first prominent composer to use it extensively.

column2: _Equal temperament_ means simply dividing the octave into twelve equal parts, thus causing all scales (as played on keyboard instruments at least) to sound exactly alike.
column3: underscore Equal temperament underscore means simply dividing the octave into twelve equal parts, thus causing all scales (as played on keyboard instruments at least) to sound exactly alike.

column2: To show the practicability of equal temperament Bach wrote a series of 48 _preludes and fugues_, two in each major and two in each minor key.
column3: To show the practicability of equal temperament Bach wrote a series of forty eight underscore preludes and fugues underscore, two in each major and two in each minor key.

column2: He called the collection "The Well-tempered Clavichord."

column2: Various _standards of pitch_ have existed at different times in the last two centuries, and even now there is no absolute uniformity although conditions are much better than they were even twenty-five years ago.

column2: Scientists use what is known as the "scientific standard" (sometimes called the "philosophic standard"), viz., 256 double vibrations for "middle C." This pitch is not in actual use for musical purposes, but is retained for theoretical purposes because of its convenience of computation (being a power of 2).
column3: Scientists use what is known as the "scientific standard" (sometimes called the "philosophic standard"), viz., two hundred fifty six double vibrations for "middle c" This pitch is not in actual use for musical purposes, but is retained for theoretical purposes because of its convenience of computation (being a power of two).

column2: In 1885 a conference of musicians at Vienna ratified the pitch giving Middle C 261 vibrations, this having been adopted by the French as their official pitch some 26 years before.
column3: In eighteen eighty five a conference of musicians at Vienna ratified the pitch giving Middle C two hundred sixty one vibrations, this having been adopted by the French as their official pitch some twenty six years before.

column2: In 1891 a convention of piano manufacturers at Philadelphia adopted this same pitch for the United States, and it has been in practically universal use ever since.

column2: This pitch (giving Middle C 261 vibrations) is known as "International Pitch."
